awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract 

This project advances the progress of science by exploring how to control magnetic properties by making materials in new and very well controlled ways, and evaluating what new applications may be realized with such magnetic materials.  Advances in magnetism are integral to new sensors, computing technologies, energy efficiency, and data storage, all of which impact US health, prosperity, and national defense.    The project may also benefit manufacturers that use advanced magnetic materials in their products, which will help the US maintain technological superiority.  Additionally, this project will support the training of young scientists so that they become familiar with modern research techniques and scientific collaboration, and ultimately develop the skills needed thrive in the US scientific and engineering workforce.  
 
Technical Abstract

The goals of this work are to create and investigate nanoscale magnetic heterostructures that contain intentional distributions of magnetic properties.    We will investigate how well-controlled composition gradients in magnetic structures can lead to new functions that may enable the design of new devices relevant to applications such as: magnetic recording and data storage; telecommunications; and energy harvesting.  Focus areas include thermally tunable exchange coupling in magnetic films; magnonic waveguides; and graded magnetic structures for electrical energy generation via spin motive forces. Understanding how to define and control magnetic properties with temperature will have implications for energy harvesting and energy assisted magnetic recording.  Understanding how magnons propagate in inhomogeneous magnetic materials may impact the future of telecommunications and enable novel computing architectures with reduced energy requirements.   Understanding the novel phenomenon of spin motive force may lead to energy harvesting and advanced battery technologies.  The artificially structured materials will be fabricated by thin film deposition techniques, and their physical properties will be characterized using magnetometry, diffraction, transport, and neutron scattering in collaboration with national laboratories.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this work were to create and investigate nanoscale magnetic heterostructures that contain intentional distributions of magnetic properties. We investigated how well-controlled composition gradients in magnetic structures can lead to new functions that may enable the design of new devices relevant to applications such as: magnetic recording and data storage; telecommunications; and energy harvesting.

 We fabricated multilayer structures in which each layer has distinct temperature at which it becomes magnetic, leading that structure to exhibit thermally tunable magnetic properties. These films were analyzed by magnetization measurements, X-ray reflectometry, and polarized neutron reflectometry (PNR).   PNR measurements were conducted in collaboration with a scientist from the NIST Center for Neutron Research.   

 We found the coupling between two outer magnetic layers to be strongly temperature-dependent when they were separated by a middle layer that underwent a transition from a paramagnetic to ferromagnetic state at a certain temperature: there was negligible coupling above that temperature and strong coupling below that temperature, with a tunable coupling between these extremes. Polarized neutron reflectometry was used to measure the depth profile of the magnetic order in the system, allowing us to correlate the magnetic order parameter with the coupling strength. As a demonstration of potential functionality of such a system as a temperature-dependent sensor, we showed that the two outer magnetic layers spontaneously flip their magnetic poles from an antiparallel to a parallel configuration once the middle layer became magnetic.

 The grant also provided research training for a number of junior scientists, including four undergraduate students, two masters students, one post-doctoral researcher, and one high school student.  The post-doctoral researcher was mentored on technical writing, project management, experiment design, and scientific collaboration. She also joined Women in Science at RIT, where she received additional mentorship from other faculty at RIT on how to follow the academic path to professorship.  She received a faculty position a state university after working on this project.

 


Last Modified: 01/06/2023
Modified by: Casey W Miller
